docs.title: Exercise 1 - Basic Nodes, Topics, and Services
docs.description: In this exercise, you'll create your first ROS 2 nodes, implement publisher/subscriber communication, and create a simple service. This will solidify your understanding of the fundamental ROS 2 concepts.

frontMatter.title: Exercise 1 - Basic Nodes, Topics, and Services

next.title: Chapter 2 - Integrating Python Agents with ROS 2 via rclpy

docs.title: Chapter 1 - Fundamentals of ROS 2 Nodes, Topics, and Services
docs.description: Welcome to the fundamentals of ROS 2! This chapter will introduce you to the core concepts that make up the Robot Operating System 2 (ROS 2) middleware.

frontMatter.title: Chapter 1 - Fundamentals of ROS 2 Nodes, Topics, and Services

previous.title: Introduction to Physical AI & Humanoid Robotics

docs.title: Introduction to ROS 2 Concepts
docs.description: This introduction covers the foundational concepts of ROS 2 (Robot Operating System 2) that you'll need to understand before diving deeper into the educational module. ROS 2 is a flexible framework for writing robot software, providing services designed for a heterogeneous computer cluster.

next.title: Exercise 1 - Basic Nodes, Topics, and Services

docs.title: ROS 2 Installation and Environment Setup
docs.description: This guide will help you set up your ROS 2 environment for the educational module. Follow these steps to ensure your system is properly configured for ROS 2 development.

previous.title: Chapter 1 - Fundamentals of ROS 2 Nodes, Topics, and Services

docs.title: Exercise 2 - Python Agent Integration with ROS 2
docs.description: In this exercise, you'll create a Python-based AI agent that integrates with ROS 2 systems using the rclpy library. You'll implement sensor data processing and control command publishing to bridge the gap between AI software and robotics hardware.

frontMatter.title: Exercise 2 - Python Agent Integration with ROS 2

previous.title: Chapter 2 - Integrating Python Agents with ROS 2 via rclpy

next.title: Chapter 3 - Modeling Humanoid Robots with URDF

docs.title: Chapter 2 - Integrating Python Agents with ROS 2 via rclpy
docs.description: This chapter focuses on integrating Python-based AI agents with ROS 2 systems using the rclpy library. You'll learn how to bridge the gap between AI software and robotics hardware.

frontMatter.title: Chapter 2 - Integrating Python Agents with ROS 2 via rclpy

previous.title: Exercise 1 - Basic Nodes, Topics, and Services

next.title: Exercise 2 - Python Agent Integration with ROS 2

docs.title: Complete ROS 2 Integration - All Concepts Combined
docs.description: This document demonstrates how all three chapters work together in a complete ROS 2 system. We'll show how ROS 2 fundamentals, Python agent integration, and URDF modeling concepts integrate to create a functional robotic system.

frontMatter.title: Complete ROS 2 Integration - All Concepts Combined

previous.title: Exercise 3 - Humanoid Robot Modeling with URDF

next.title: Module Summary - The Robotic Nervous System

docs.title: Exercise 3 - Humanoid Robot Modeling with URDF
docs.description: In this exercise, you'll create your own humanoid robot model using URDF (Unified Robot Description Format). You'll learn how to define links, joints, and materials to create a complete robot model that can be visualized and simulated.

frontMatter.title: Exercise 3 - Humanoid Robot Modeling with URDF

previous.title: Chapter 3 - Modeling Humanoid Robots with URDF

next.title: Complete ROS 2 Integration - All Concepts Combined

docs.title: Module Summary - The Robotic Nervous System
docs.description: Congratulations! You've completed the comprehensive module on "The Robotic Nervous System (ROS 2)". This module covered three essential areas of ROS 2 development for robotics applications.

frontMatter.title: Module Summary - The Robotic Nervous System

previous.title: Complete ROS 2 Integration - All Concepts Combined

docs.title: Chapter 3 - Modeling Humanoid Robots with URDF
docs.description: This chapter covers the Unified Robot Description Format (URDF), which is an XML format for representing robot models including kinematics and dynamics. You'll learn how to model humanoid robots for simulation and control.

frontMatter.title: Chapter 3 - Modeling Humanoid Robots with URDF

previous.title: Exercise 2 - Python Agent Integration with ROS 2

next.title: Exercise 3 - Humanoid Robot Modeling with URDF

docs.title: Gazebo Setup Guide for Physics Simulation
docs.description: This guide provides comprehensive instructions for installing and setting up Gazebo specifically for physics simulation in digital twin applications. We'll cover the installation process, configuration, and verification steps needed to create realistic physics simulations.

frontMatter.title: Gazebo Setup Guide for Physics Simulation

docs.title: Chapter 1 - Physics Simulation in Gazebo
docs.description: Welcome to Chapter 1 of the Digital Twin educational module! This chapter focuses on Gazebo physics simulation, which forms the foundational component of our digital twin system. Gazebo provides realistic physics simulation that accurately models the behavior of robots and their interactions with the environment.

previous.title: Module Summary - The Robotic Nervous System

next.title: Gazebo Setup Guide for Physics Simulation

docs.title: Troubleshooting Guide for Common Gazebo Issues
docs.description: This comprehensive troubleshooting guide addresses common issues encountered when working with Gazebo for digital twin applications. The guide is organized by issue category with detailed solutions and preventive measures.

frontMatter.title: Troubleshooting Guide for Common Gazebo Issues

next.title: Unity Setup Diagrams and Screenshots Guide

docs.title: Chapter 2 - High-Fidelity Rendering in Unity
docs.description: Welcome to Chapter 2 of the Digital Twin educational module! This chapter focuses on Unity for high-fidelity rendering and visualization, which provides the visual component of our digital twin system. Unity enables realistic rendering of robot models, environments, and human-robot interactions that complement the physics simulation provided by Gazebo.

next.title: Unity Installation and Setup for Robotics

docs.title: Realistic Material and Lighting Setup for Robots
docs.description: This section provides comprehensive guidance on creating realistic materials and lighting setups for robot visualization in Unity. Proper material and lighting configuration is essential for high-fidelity digital twin rendering that accurately represents real-world robot appearance and behavior.

frontMatter.title: Realistic Material and Lighting Setup for Robots

previous.title: Robot Model Import and Setup Tutorial

next.title: User Interface Controls for Robot Interaction

docs.title: Optimization Techniques for High-Fidelity Rendering
docs.description: This section provides comprehensive optimization techniques for achieving high-fidelity rendering in Unity while maintaining real-time performance for digital twin applications. These techniques balance visual quality with computational efficiency.

docs.title: Robot Model Import and Setup Tutorial
docs.description: This tutorial provides comprehensive guidance on importing and setting up robot models in Unity for digital twin applications. You'll learn how to bring 3D robot models into Unity, configure them for visualization, and prepare them for integration with robotics systems.

frontMatter.title: Robot Model Import and Setup Tutorial

previous.title: Unity Installation and Setup for Robotics

next.title: Realistic Material and Lighting Setup for Robots

docs.title: Unity Documentation Citations
docs.description: This document provides citations to official Unity documentation and robotics packages used in the digital twin visualization chapter. These references support the technical content and provide additional resources for learners.

next.title: Chapter 3 - Sensor Simulation in Digital Twins

docs.title: Unity Installation and Setup for Robotics
docs.description: This guide provides comprehensive instructions for installing and setting up Unity specifically for robotics visualization and digital twin applications. We'll cover the installation process, robotics-specific packages, and configuration needed for high-fidelity rendering.

frontMatter.title: Unity Installation and Setup for Robotics

next.title: Robot Model Import and Setup Tutorial

docs.title: Unity-ROS Integration Code Examples
docs.description: This section provides comprehensive code examples for integrating Unity with ROS (Robot Operating System) for digital twin applications. These examples demonstrate how to establish communication between Unity and ROS systems, enabling real-time data exchange for visualization and control.

previous.title: Unity Setup Diagrams and Screenshots Guide

docs.title: User Interface Controls for Robot Interaction
docs.description: This section provides comprehensive guidance on creating intuitive user interfaces for interacting with robot digital twins in Unity. Effective UI design is crucial for operators to monitor, control, and understand robot behavior in the digital twin environment.

frontMatter.title: User Interface Controls for Robot Interaction

docs.title: Humanoid-Specific Configuration
docs.description: This document details the configuration parameters and settings required to adapt the Navigation2 framework for humanoid robots. Unlike wheeled robots, humanoid robots have unique kinematic and dynamic constraints that must be considered in the navigation system.

previous.title: Nav2 Installation and Setup Guide for Humanoid Applications

docs.title: Chapter 3: Nav2 - Humanoid Path Planning
docs.description: This chapter covers the Navigation2 (Nav2) framework specifically tailored for humanoid robots. We'll explore how to adapt traditional wheeled robot navigation approaches for bipedal locomotion and complex humanoid movement patterns.

metadata.title: Welcome
metadata.description: Docusaurus blogging features are powered by the blog plugin.

blogPosts.content:
[Docusaurus blogging features](https://docusaurus.io/docs/blog) are powered by the [blog plugin](https://docusaurus.io/docs/api/plugins/@docusaurus/plugin-content-blog).

Here are a few tips you might find useful.

<!-- truncate -->

Simply add Markdown files (or folders) to the `blog` directory.

Regular blog authors can be added to `authors.yml`.

The blog post date can be extracted from filenames, such as:

- `2019-05-30-welcome.md`
- `2019-05-30-welcome/index.md`

A blog post folder can be convenient to co-locate blog post images:

![Docusaurus Plushie](./docusaurus-plushie-banner.jpeg)

The blog supports tags as well!

**And if you don't want a blog**: just delete this directory, and use `blog: false` in your Docusaurus config.

metadata.title: MDX Blog Post
metadata.description: Blog posts support Docusaurus Markdown features, such as MDX.

blogPosts.content:
Blog posts support [Docusaurus Markdown features](https://docusaurus.io/docs/markdown-features), such as [MDX](https://mdxjs.com/).

:::tip

Use the power of React to create interactive blog posts.

:::

{/* truncate */}

For example, use JSX to create an interactive button:

```js
<button onClick={() => alert('button clicked!')}>Click me!</button>
```

<button onClick={() => alert('button clicked!')}>Click me!</button>

metadata.title: Long Blog Post
metadata.description: This is the summary of a very long blog post,

blogPosts.content:
This is the summary of a very long blog post,

Use a `<!--` `truncate` `-->` comment to limit blog post size in the list view.

<!-- truncate -->
